bibl.title: Letter fragment from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 21, 1922

div1.p: Hanson reports on the conclusion of the yellow fever campaign in Peru. He encourages Carter to file all his expense receipts since the exchange rate has improved.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 21, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
May 21, 1922.
NUMERO
____
Dr. H.R. Carter,
2121 California St. N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
It is some time since I last wrote you, and if
I am not mistaken I have two unanswered letters since that time. One
is the one you wrote in which you enclosed copy of the letter to Miss
Read about the Chanchamayo Valley and the outside zone for our campa-
ign. As things are now it is too late to discuss what further we are
to do because yesterday I stopped all work in the field in all De-
partments, and we now consider our task finished, with the exception
of compiling our data. This I assume is good news to you. I feel cer-
tain that the thing is done and I believe well done. It is a great
relief to be able to think and feel that way after almost three
years of struggle with the pesky thing. Naturally if I had known as
much about it when I commenced as I do now we probably would have
gotten through very much sooner.

I expect to keep Mr. Guldstarnd and two of the clerks at
work until about the 15th of June getting all the accounts well
worked up and a resume of statistical data on the work in such
shape that I can write up the report in proper manner. From all
indications our figures on the different lines of our work all
pass the one million mark. The total number of house visits seems to
be somewhere about a million and a half, the container inspections
about twice that number and the total number of fish distributed
will also pass the one million mark. I think it will be work while
for the historical records of this campaign to get all this properly
Dr. H.R. Carter, 2.
tabulated. I have a curiosity to know the unit cost in the work
done in this campaign.

The total amount of funds from the International Health
Board is a little less than $110,000.00, and that from the Govern-
ment about Lp. 4000.00. I expect to have all returns in by the end
of the month of May when in a few days wel will get up the final
statement for the Comptroller of the Rockefeller Foundation and for
the Government of Peru. In all I have drawn chekcs for about $115,000,
but I have a balance on hand in pounds and some in dollars from what
the Government recently paid me, which brings the total down to less
than $110,000,

And in speaking of money I wish to say that they other a
day I cabled to the New York Office for Miss Read to inform you that
the exchange was rising and for you to turn your receipts over to the
bank in New York with authotity for me to convert the money your have
here at such a time as we shall find the exchange favourable, which
I think may come soon. The bankers expect the exchange to go up to
about four soon and if it does that would be the time to convert what
you have on deposit here. The present rise in the exchange is due to
the renewed cotton shipping, and as the shipping will be only a tem-
porary measure it is also thought that the rise in the exchange will
only last for a short time, hence your money should be converted as
soon as one can be sure that you are not going to lose on what you
originally deposited.

I started this letter Sunday but was interrupted.
Today I have cabled the International Health Board that I closed
all Campaign work on the 20th, and that I expected to have all the
statistical data collected by June 15, and that I was making an
